eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ButtonStates
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Use any object as a button and change appearance according to user interactions.
description: Use the "Button states" behavior to track user interactions with an object, including:
- Hovered
- Pressed
- Clicked
- Idle
Add additional behaviors to make juicy buttons with animated responses to user input:
- Size
- Color
- Animation
- Object effects

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sway
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Sway objects like grass in the wind.
description: This extension makes objects sway at different times.
It can be used to:
- Simulate grass and plant movement swaying in the wind
- Animate seaweed in an underwater environment
- Give flames a flickering look
Set *Center* and *Origin* points to the center base of the object for best results.
Check out [this demo](https://gd.games/bubble/swayexamples) to see what this extension can do.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Sway multiple instances of an object at different times - useful for random grass swaying.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Sway

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: EllipseMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
description: It allows objects to move:
- on an ellipsis or arcs
- smoothly vertically or horizontally (by setting one radius to 0)
- on a sine wave (by adding a force)
Instances will start their movement from their initial position on the scene.
The center position will be decided according to the "initial direction" angle and the radius.
It can be used for:
- Making objects float, such as powerups or coins
- Moving platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
- Making a player constantly turn right or left ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://star-seeker))

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: RectangleMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move objects in a rectangular pattern.
description: Move objects in a rectangular pattern with easing functions from the Tween extension.
It can be used for:
- Moveable platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
- Moving along the border of another object (inside, center, outside)
The platformer example uses this extension ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer)).
This game shows how to make objects move around the border of another object ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://moving-saw-platformer)).
This example can be used to test different settings ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://rectangular-movement)).

eventsFunctions.description: Distance from an object to the closest edge of a second object.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Distance from an object to the closest edge of a second object
eventsFunctions.name: DistanceToClosestEdge
eventsFunctions.sentence: Distance from _PARAM1_ to the closest edge of _PARAM2_

events.comment: If point is inside rectangle, just use min distance

parameters:
min(
min(
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY() - CenterObject.BoundingBoxTop(), 
CenterObject.BoundingBoxBottom() - MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY()),
min(
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX() - CenterObject.BoundingBoxLeft(), 
CenterObject.BoundingBoxRight() - MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX())
)

events.comment: If point is outside rectangle, find distance to clamped position on rectangle

parameters:
DistanceBetweenPositions(
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX(),
MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY(),
clamp(MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterX(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxLeft(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxRight()),
clamp(MovingObject.BoundingBoxCenterY(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxTop(), CenterObject.BoundingBoxBottom())
)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: MazeGenerator
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create a maze made of a grid of rectangular cells. Walls are created randomly so that every cell is reachable through a random path through the maze.
description: Provides functions for generating mazes.
Use **GenerateMaze** action to set up a maze with a particular size and give it a name (MazeID). The maze is stored in scene variables, to be used with other functions by specifying the MazeID.
There are three other actions that create sprite objects you can use to place the maze into the scene:
**CreateMazeFloorObjects** : create tiles for each cell in the maze
**CreateMazeWallObjects**: create objects between each cell. Useful for walls
**CreateMazeCornerObjects**: create objects on the point between 4 cell corners. Can be useful to improve maze visuals
There are plenty of other helper functions for getting/setting maze properites or get helpful information. In particular:
**CheckMazeWall**: a condition to use in event sheet to test which walls exist for a cell
**FindMazePath**: creates a scene variable array containing a sequence of directions to go from one cell to another cell

Finally, there is a **MazeObject** behavior that can be attached to wall or floor objects to provide some additional helper conditions, expressions, and actions. See the example gdevelop file in the help URL for examples of its use.

eventsFunctions.description: Specify the overall size of a maze, and the size of the tile "cells" inside the maze. Walls are randomly generated to form the maze. The maze is stored in memory, and can be referenced using a name called MazeID that is chosen here. The maze generator extension comes with other actions that reference this mazeID, which can be used to create actual wall and floor objects to place the maze into the scene.
eventsFunctions.name: GenerateMaze
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create a random maze called _PARAM7_ at point x=_PARAM1_, y=_PARAM2_ of width _PARAM3_ and height _PARAM4_, made with _PARAM5_ by _PARAM6_ cells

events.comment: The maze is initialized with 4 boolean arrays (rows * columns elements), one for each direction to track presence of a wall. From a random starting point, a loop moves an index variable through the maze picking a random direction each time to remove a wall and create a path. Once there are no more adjacent cells not yet visited (another array "FloorToDo" tracks visited or not visited yet), the completed cell is removed from the "FloorInProgress" array and it goes back to a previous cell  to try additional directions from there. Once all cells are completed the resulting arrays are stored in a structure to be used with the other maze  functions
Pick a random cell to start from, append it to an array that will track the in-progress spaces in the maze
Try each direction in a random order to see if maze can build in that direction (wall exists in that direction, next cell in that direction hasn't been completed yet)

The conditions to check for each direction are:
1. Check the direction picked randomly, stored in Directions variable
2. There is a wall that could be removed to make a new path in that direction ( ...Wall arrays contain "TRUE" if there is a wall there. All walls initialize as existing then we remove some to create the path)
3. Treat the maze boundaries as impassible. For top and bottom edge, the cell Index number being moved to has to be within the total number of cells in the maze. For the left and right edge, (index Modulo # of columns = zero) for cells on the left edge, and (index Modulo # of columns = # of columns - 1) for cells on the right edge
4. Don't move to a space we have already visited before (FloorTodo array starts as true for all cells, goes to false once visited). This prevents the maze from being too easy by having too many ways to get to each cell in the maze
5. Once a valid direction is found, skip all the other directions (FoundDirection is true once a direction is found). If the first direction it finds isn't valid, then the loop repeats again to try one of the other directions instead
If no valid directions are found, the cell is completed and can be removed from the inprogress list

parameters.description: Top-left point, X coordinate of maze in scene
parameters.name: MazeX

parameters.description: Top-left point, Y coordinate of maze in scene
parameters.name: MazeY

eventsFunctions.description: Finds a path through a maze between two cells, storing the result in a scene variable array.
eventsFunctions.name: FindMazePath
eventsFunctions.sentence: Find path through maze _PARAM1_ from row _PARAM2_ column _PARAM3_ to row _PARAM4_ column _PARAM5_, store result as _PARAM6_

events.comment: Starting from the start cell, traverse through the maze picking random directions until the end cell is encountered. At each step, record the direction taken as a string in a new array.

"Floor in progress" array is initialized with starting cell number. This loop adds additional cells to the array from random directions, traversing the maze. Once no additional paths are found for a cell, it gets removed from the "Floor in progress" array. At that point the search moves back to a previous cell and looks for another direction to go in. This continues until the first cell is removed from the array (all directions explored). Thus, once the "floor in progress" array is empty, the maze traversal is complete.
If the current cell is the end cell, check if the path variable is shortest if so make it the new shortest path
Try each direction in a random order to see if no wall is there and haven't been to the cell in that direction yet

The conditions to check for each direction are:
1. Check the direction picked randomly, stored in Directions variable
2. There is no wall in that direction, add continue with next floor in that direction
3. Don't move to a space we have already visited before (FloorTodo array starts as true for all cells, goes to false once visited). 
4. Once a valid direction is found, skip all the other directions (FoundDirection is true once a direction is found). If the first direction it finds isn't valid, then the loop repeats again to try one of the other directions instead

Once all directions are checked, no new exit path found, mark the cell as processed and remove it from the "FloorInProgress" array list. Next loop will go back to previous cell (last cell now in the "FloorInProgress" list) to check if any more directions haven't been explored yet from there

parameters.longDescription: This will be the name of the child array stored in the __MazeGeneratorPath scene structure variable
parameters.name: StructureName

eventsFunctions.description: Returns how many cells away from a cell with at least three exits.
eventsFunctions.name: MazeCellDepth

events.comment: Starting from the start cell, traverse through the maze picking random directions until getting to a cell with at least 3 exits. This can be used, for example, for counting how deep a dead-end is. Useful to add extra treasure, add additional exits etc. to less
Try each direction in a random order to see if maze can build in that direction (wall exists in that direction, next cell in that direction hasn't been completed yet)

The conditions to check for each direction are:
1. Check the direction picked randomly, stored in Directions variable
2. There is no wall in that direction, add continue with next floor in that direction
3. Don't move to a space we have already visited before (FloorTodo array starts as true for all cells, goes to false once visited). This prevents the maze from being too easy by having too many ways to get to each cell in the maze
4. Once a valid direction is found, skip all the other directions (FoundDirection is true once a direction is found). If the first direction it finds isn't valid, then the loop repeats again to try one of the other directions instead
If we've reached a cell with at least three exits, check if the new distance is the shortest so far

eventsFunctions.description: Traverse maze Test.
eventsFunctions.name: TraverseMaze

events.comment: This traverses a previously built array. Serves no purpose (set as private), except to provide a template for other functions
Pick a random cell to start from, append it to an array that will track the in-progress spaces in the maze
Try each direction in a random order to see if maze can build in that direction (wall exists in that direction, next cell in that direction hasn't been completed yet)

The conditions to check for each direction are:
1. Check the direction picked randomly, stored in Directions variable
2. There is no wall in that direction, add continue with next floor in that direction
3. Don't move to a space we have already visited before (FloorTodo array starts as true for all cells, goes to false once visited). This prevents the maze from being too easy by having too many ways to get to each cell in the maze
4. Once a valid direction is found, skip all the other directions (FoundDirection is true once a direction is found). If the first direction it finds isn't valid, then the loop repeats again to try one of the other directions instead

events.comment: First, convert row and column number into maze array index and store it in a scene variable to modify the wall arrays
Also modify the wall arrays in the opposite direction in the cell adjacent

eventsFunctions.description: The number of directions with walls.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Number of Walls in a Maze Cell
eventsFunctions.name: MazeNumWalls

eventsFunctions.description: For a previously created maze, create maze floor objects that will tile the cells of the maze.
eventsFunctions.name: CreateMazeFloorObjects
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create _PARAM2_ floors for maze _PARAM1_ in layer _PARAM3_

events.comment:
The maze information (number of rows and columns) is looked up from __MazeGenerator structure variable which was created when the Generate Maze Action was used. This creates a sprite object for each cell in the maze (acting as a floor object)
Some object variables are created in case the MazeObject behavior is being used (its optional, simply enables some useful object functions)

eventsFunctions.description: For a previously created maze, create maze wall objects along the edges of the cells of the maze.
eventsFunctions.name: CreateMazeWallObjects
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create _PARAM2_ and _PARAM3_ walls for maze _PARAM1_ in layer _PARAM4_

events.comment:
The maze information (number of rows and columns) is looked up from __MazeGenerator structure variable which was created when the Generate Maze Action was used. This creates a sprite object between each cell in the maze, to represent walls
Some object variables are created in case the MazeObject behavior is being used (its optional, simply enables some useful object functions)

For walls above cell
The extra condition is to prevent duplicate walls (cells are processed from top left to bottom right; "above" walls are first created as "below" walls for the cell above already processed)

For walls to the left of cells
The extra condition is to prevent duplicate walls (cells are processed from top left to bottom right; "left" walls are first created as "right" walls for the cell to the left already processed)
For walls to the right of cells
For walls below cells

eventsFunctions.description: For a previously created maze, create maze corner objects at the intersection point of maze cells.
eventsFunctions.name: CreateMazeCornerObjects
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create _PARAM2_ corners for maze _PARAM1_ in layer _PARAM3_

events.comment:
The maze information (number of rows and columns) is looked up from __MazeGenerator structure variable which was created when the Generate Maze Action was used. This creates a sprite object at the intersection point between four cells, if there are two walls interseting there to act as a corner
Some object variables are created in case the MazeObject behavior is being used (its optional, simply enables some useful object functions)
For top left corner, check if two walls meet there in any orientation
For top right corner, check if two walls meet there in any orientation
For bottom left corner, check if two walls meet there in any orientation
For bottom right corner, check if two walls meet there in any orientation

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: This behavior adds some helper functions to be used with Maze Generator extension, that can be used in the event sheet. Search for "Maze" in the events editor to find them after attaching this to an object. Objects with this behavior need to be used with the "CreateMazeFloorObject", "CreateMazeWallObjects" or "CreateCornerObjects" functions of the maze generator in order to benefit from the helper functions. For example, "CheckMazeObjecetLocation" condition filters objects from a row number and column number of a maze.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ShakeObject
description: Shake an object (position, angle or scale).
It can be used for:
- Hit or impact
- Object slowly rocking back and forth (like a ship)
- Simulate engine vibration, earthquake, or pulsing
The top-down RPG example uses this extension for damage animations ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://top-down-rpg)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Shake objects with translation and rotation.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Shake an object, using one or more ways to shake (position, angle). Make sure to "Stop shaking" before starting a new shake if it uses different parameters.
eventsFunctions.name: ShakeObject_PositionAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake object _PARAM0_ for _PARAM2_ seconds. Modify position amplitude _PARAM3_ on X axis and _PARAM4_ on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM5_.  Wait _PARAM6_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM7_

events.comment: Start/Reset duration timer
Pass input parameters to global variables so that onScenePostEvents can use them
Determine if the shake should keep going until stopped
Add default values if none were provided
If duration is less than a single shake, increase duration to make 1 full shake
Detect initial shake
Initiate the onScenePostEvents function

parameters.description: Amplitude of postion shake in X direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerX

parameters.description: Amplitude of position shake in Y direction (in pixels)  (For example: 5)
parameters.longDescription: Use a negative number to make the single-shake move in the opposite direction.
parameters.name: PowerY

parameters.description: Amplitude of angle rotation shake (in degrees)  (For example: 5)
parameters.name: PowerAngle

parameters.description: Amount of time between shakes (in seconds) (Default: 0.08)
parameters.longDescription: For a single-shake effect, set it to the same value as "Duration".
parameters.name: TimeBetweenShakes

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Save that initial shake has been processed
Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame
Increase change for the first half of the shake (move away from original values)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Decrease change the second half of the shake (return to original position)
Change position
Save movement to calculate drift
Change angle
Save movement to calculate drift
Stop shaking when the duration has been reached (or if the stop shaking function was called)

parameters.name: PowerScale

events.comment: Keep object shaking forever (if desired)
Run once before every shake movement

events.name: Correct for drift and reset drift tracking variables

events.comment: Move to correct any drift from previous shake
Reset drift detection variables
Calculate Position Shake
PositionDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude * [-1 or 1]
Make initial shake NOT random so users can set a direction for a one-shake effect
After initial shake pick a random direction
Calculate Rotation (angle) shake
Every "even" shake, rotate clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Every "odd" shake, rotate counter-clockwise
AngleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude
Calculate Scale shake
Calculate object scale displacement, with linear decay over time
ScaleDisplacement = (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100
Every even shake, increase scale
Every "odd" shake, decrease scale
ScaleDisplacement = -1 * (DesiredDuration - RunningTimer) / DesiredDuration * Amplitude *  1/100

Calculate the fraction of shake that occured during this frame

description: Loads a (static) JSON resource from your project files into a global, scene, or object variable.
NEVER use this to load your game.json into a variable - this would increase your game size by a lot and make your whole project file available for anyone to open!

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/), D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: DraggableSliderControl
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value.
description: Draws a draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value.
The value range, tick spacing, and the appearance of the slider can be defined with properties.
How to use:
- Add this behavior a **Shape Painter** object
- Place an instance of that shape painter on the screen where you want the slider to appear
- Use the "Value" expression to find the Value based on the position of the slider
Tips:
- You can disable the slider to prevent a user from interacting with it
- You can set the Value of the slider and the slider will move to the correct position
Further details can be found in [this tutorial video](https://youtu.be/iiTUwdAT_hs).

breaking: - Track thickness and length properties replaced track width and height. These 2 properties must be set again if they were different from the default size.
- Hidden sliders can be dragged. The "enable" action must be used to disable them.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Let users select a numerical value by dragging a slider.

events.comment: Make sure object doesn't get re-drawn every frame
Use correct min value (instead of always starting at 0)
Set track height function (which enforces valid thumb sizes)
Start halo at same size as thumb
Track where the mouse is (in relation to object)
Move slider when being dragged
End sliding and update variables
Update "Value" based on the location of the thumb
Grow halo even more when pressed
Detect hover/touch/click (but only if the layer and object is visible, and the object is not already being dragged)
Detect mouse clicks near track, start dragging
Reset hover detection
Grow halo when hovered
Shrink halo to zero when not hovered
Redraw slider only when halo is not at final size
Set inactive track parameters (by default, use thumb color)
Draw inactive track
Draw half circle at end of track (inactive side)
Set active track parameters (by default, use thumb color)
Draw active track (2 pixels bigger than property)
Draw half circle at end of track (active side)
Prepare halo
Draw halo (it will grow or shrink as needed)
Use a more opaque halo while being dragged (it will grow or shrink as needed)
Prepare thumb settings
Draw Circle thumb
Draw Rectangle thumb

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelSpriteSlider
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value.
description: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value. The slider can be customized with sprites.
There are ready-to-use sliders in the asset-store [settings UI pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=settings-ui-settings-ui).

changelog.breaking: - Sliders now use "variants", allowing easy swapping of their visual aspect. You will have to make some adjustments to existing sliders in your project. Follow this [migration documentation](https://wiki.gdevelop.io/gdevelop5/objects/custom-objects-prefab-template/migrate-to-variants/) to do these changes.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sticker
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make objects follow the position and rotation of the object they are stuck to.
description: This extension can be useful to:
- Stick accessories to moving objects
- Animate a skeleton
- Delete an object with another one
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://stick-objects)).

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

inlineCode: * Update the coordinates in the basisObject basis.
* It uses the basisObject coordinates from the previous frame.
* This way, the sticker can move relatively to it and still
// Save initial values to avoid calculus and rounding errors
* Copy the coordinates to use it the next frame.
* This method is also called by children to ensure
// If the behavior on the basis object has a different name,
// the objects will still follow their basis objects
// Follow parents 1st to avoid frame delays
// Unproportional dimensions changes won't work as expected
// if the object angle is not null but nothing more can be done
// because there is no full affine transformation on objects.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object is stuck to another object.
eventsFunctions.name: IsStuck

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Stick the object to another. Use the action to stick the object, or unstick it later.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Sticker

inlineCode: // Set up the scene sticker objects list - if not done already.
// Register this object as a sticker.

eventsFunctions.description: Stick on another object.
eventsFunctions.name: Stick

inlineCode: // An object can stick to only one object.

eventsFunctions.description: Unstick from the object it was stuck to.
eventsFunctions.name: Unstick

propertyDescriptors.label: Destroy when the object it's stuck on is destroyed
propertyDescriptors.name: IsDestroyedWithParent
